Alabama.edited-details: HB162, in addition to eliminate the requirement of marriage licenses, would have affirmed the minimum age for marriage is 16 with parental consent, which is already state law.
Alabama.unchained-details: HB162, in addition to eliminate the requirement of marriage licenses, would have affirmed the minimum age for marriage is 16 with parental consent, which is already state law.

Alaska.edited-details: SB133 would have eliminated marriage before 18, with exceptions for emancipated minors and the military exception already in law. The bill died at the end of the legislative session in March 2018.
Alaska.unchained-details: In Jan. 2018, Sen. Berta Gardner introduced SB133 to reduce child marriage: It would have eliminated marriage before 18, but still allow emancipated minors to marry. SB133 also would have kept the dangerous military exception in Alaska's current marriage-age law. But the senate never voted on it, and the bill died at the end of the legislative session in March 2018.

Arizona.edited-details: The original draft of HB2006 would have ended all marriage before 18, but was later ammended to allow anyone above 15 to marry with parental consent and if there is no more than a three-year age difference between spouses. This version passed.
Arizona.unchained-details: On Nov. 20, 2017, Rep. Michelle Ugenti-Rita introduced HB2006 to end all marriage before 18, without exceptions. On February 13, 2018, the bill was amended to allow 16- and 17-year-olds to marry with parental consent or if they are emancipated, and if there is no more than a three-year age difference between the spousal pair. On February 20, 2018, the house voted in favor of the bill. On April 2, 2018, the senate voted in favor of the bill. On April 12, 2018, the governor signed the bill into law. Unchained hopes Arizona legislators pass additional legislators to protect 16- and 17-year-olds, who face the highest risk of forced child marriage.

California.edited-details: SB273 would have ended all marriage before 18, but was ammended to include an exception for court ordered permission after a 30-day waiting period. This current version is now pending in the assembly.
California.unchained-details: On Mar. 17, 2017, Sen. Jerry Hill introduced SB273 to end all marriage before 18, without exceptions. Unfortunately, the bill was later amended repeatedly and weakened to the point where Unchained fears it would do more harm than good. A version of the weakened bill passed unanimously in the senate in May; the bill is now pending in the assembly. Unchained urges legislators to vote NO on the current version of SB273. An unmarried person under 18 years of age may be issued a marriage license upon obtaining a court order granting permission; by court order if one or both of the parties are 15 years of age or younger, the parties shall be eligible to request a marriage license no earlier than 30 days from the time the court order was issued.

California 2.edited-details: AB2882 requires consent from at least one parent in addition to the already state mandated court order for underage marriage.
California 2.unchained-details:
This bill would instead require the court order and written
consent of at least one of the parents or the guardian of each
underage person to be filed with the clerk of the court, not just the court order

Connecticut.edited-details: HB5442 started out as a bill to end all child marriage, but was ammended to allow anyone 16 and older to marry with consent from themselves, a parent and a judge.
Connecticut.unchained-details: In January 2017, Rep. Michelle Cook introduced HB5442 to end all child marriage. But the legislature passed a weakened version of the bill with a dangerous exception: 16- and 17-year-olds may marry with consent from themselves, a parent and a judge. The governor signed the weakened version on June 20, 2017. Unchained hopes Connecticut will pass additional legislation to eliminate the dangerous exception.

Delaware.edited-details: HB337 ends all child marriage in the state of Delaware without exceptions. Deleware is the first state to do so.
Delaware.unchained-details: On March 13, 2018, Rep. Kimberly Williams introduced HB337 to end all child marriage, without exceptions. On March 28, 2018, the bill passed in the house. On May 3, 2018, the senate unanimously passed HB337. On May 9, 2018, Governor John Carney signed HB337 into law. Delaware is the first U.S. state to end all child marriage, without exceptions.

Florida.edited-details: SB140 and HB335 originally sought to end all child marriage without exceptions, but later was amended to allow 17-year-olds to marry with parental consent and if there is no more than a two-year age gap between the spousal pair.
Florida.unchained-details: In Aug. 2017, Sen. Lizbeth Benacquisto filed SB140 to end all child marriage, without exceptions. Rep. Jeanette Nunez later filed the house version of the bill, HB335. Both houses of the legislature approved SB140 in March 2018, after it was amended to allow 17-year-olds to marry with parental consent if there is no more than a two-year age difference between the spousal pair. The governor signed the bill on Mar. 23, 2018. Unchained hopes Florida passes additional legislation to eliminate the dangerous exception, under which parents can still force their children to marry.

Iowa.edited-details: HF442 would enforce the state law already in place where minors seeking to marry must obtain permission from a parent or court.
Iowa.unchained-details: HF442 would enforce the state law already in place where minors seeking to marry must obtain permission from a parent or court.

Kentucky.edited-details: SB48 allows 17-year-olds to marry with parental consent.
Kentucky.unchained-details: On Jan. 3, 2018, Sen. Julie Raque Adams introduced SB48 to end marriage for children 16 and younger. The bill would have allowed 17-year-olds to marry with judicial approval. The senate approved the bill on March 7, 2018, after it was amended to require 17-year-olds to have parental consent to marry (in addition to judicial approval). The house approved it on March 16, 2018. On March 29, 2018, the governor signed the bill into law. Unchained hopes Kentucky passes additional legislation to eliminate the dangerous exception, under which 17-year-olds can be forced to marry.

Louisiana.edited-details: SB463, a bill to end all child marriage without exceptions, was postponed indefinitely at the end of the 2018 legislative session.
Louisiana.unchained-details: On March 14, 2018, Sen. Karen Carter Peterson introduced SB463, a bill to end all child marriage without exceptions. On May 16, 2018, the bill was attached to a study order, effectively and indefinitely postponing it. Unchained hopes Louisiana lawmakers will introduce identical legislation in the next legislative session.

Maryland.edited-details: HB191 and SB670 would have ended all marriage before 18 and were reiterations of a bill that died in the two previous legislative sessions. They were both amended to allow 16 and 17-year-olds to marry, though the bill died at the end of the legislative session.
Maryland.unchained-details: In Jan. 2018, Del. Vanessa Atterbeary introduced HB191, to end all marriage before 18, as a reintroduction of the bill that died in the two previous legislative sessions. Sen. Robert Zirkin later introduced the senate version, SB670. In March 2018, HB191 was amended to allow 17-year-olds to marry, without any protections. The same month, SB670 was amended to allow 16- and 17-year-olds to marry, without any protections. Both bills died at the end of the legislative session on April 9, 2018. Unchained hopes Maryland lawmakers will reintroduce the same legislation to end all child marriage.

Massachusetts.edited-details: S785 and H2310 would have ended all child marriage before 18 without exception, but was indefinitely postponed and died at the end of the 2018 legislative session.
Massachusetts.unchained-details: On Jan. 20, 2017, Rep. Kay Khan and Sen. Harriette Chandler introduced S785/H2310 to end all marriage before 18, without exceptions. The judiciary committee considered the bill on May 8, 2017. On Feb. 7, 2018, the house bill was attached to a study order, effectively and indefinitely postponing it. Unchained hopes Massachusetts lawmakers will introduce identical legislation in the next legislative session.

Missouri.edited-details: HB1630, a bill to limit child marriage, was a reintroduction of a bill that died in the previous legislative session, and died in the 2018 legislative session as well.
Missouri.unchained-details: In Jan. 2018, Rep. Jean Evans introduced HB1630, to limit child marriage, as a reintroduction of a bill that died in the previous legislative session. HB1630 later died.

Missouri 2.edited-details: Unrelated bill SB655 ended child marriage for children 15 and younger, and bars anyone older than 21 from marrying a minor.
Missouri 2.unchained-details: In May 2018, Rep. Evans amended an unrelated bill, SB655, to end child marriage for children 15 and younger. SB655 would allow 16- and 17-year-olds to marry with parental consent, and would bar anyone older than 21 from marrying anyone younger than 18. The bill heads to the governor's desk.

New Hampshire.edited-details: HB499 would have eliminated all child marriage, but was downvoted and blocked from reintroduction.
New Hampshire.unchained-details: In Jan. 2017, Rep. Jacalyn Cilley introduced HB499. At first the bill allowed 16- and 17-year-olds to marry, but it was later amended to eliminate all child marriage. The House of Representatives voted no in March 2017 and blocked the bill from being reintroduced.

New Hampshire 2.edited-details: HB1597, HB1661, and HB1586 would appove marriages of anyone older than 16 unless one of the parties, if it wasn't for the marriage, would be guilty of sexual assault.
New Hampshire 2.unchained-details: In Nov. 2017, Rep. Cilley introduced HB1587 to raise the marriage age to 16. The same month, Rep. Cilley introduced HB1661 to require judges to approve marriages of 16- and 17-year-olds. Rep. Cilley also introduced HB1586 to prohibit the court from approving marriages involving a minor if the other party, but for the marriage, would be guilty of sexual assault. In March 2018, all three bills passed in the house. In May 2018, all three bills passed in the senate. The legislation now awaits the governor's signature.

New Jersey.edited-details: A3091 would have ended all child marriage without exceptions, and passed the legislature, but was conditionally vetoed by Gov. Christie in 2017.
New Jersey.unchained-details: In Feb. 2016, Asw. Nancy Munoz introduced A3091 to end all child marriage, without exceptions; Sen. Nellie Pou later introduced the senate version. A3091 passed in both houses of the legislature with overwhelming bipartisan support. But in May 2017, Gov. Christie conditionally vetoed the bill.

New Jersey 2.edited-details: A3091 was reintroduced as A865/S427 and has passed the legislature and with a signature from Gov. Murphy.
New Jersey 2.unchained-details: In Jan. 2018, the bill's sponsors reintroduced the legislation, now A865/S427. On April 12, 2018, S427 passed in the senate. The legislation remains pending in the assembly. Gov. Phil Murphy has promised his support.

New York.edited-details: A5524 and S4407, though originally would have barred all marriage under 18, was ammended to allow 17-year-olds to marry with judicial approval. It passed unanimously.
New York.unchained-details: In February 2017, Asw. Amy Paulin introduced A5524; Sen. Andrew Lanza later introduced the senate version, S4407. The bills replaced a bill Paulin had introduced the previous year that was never brought up for a vote; however, while the previous version would have eliminated all marriage before 18, the new version allowed 17-year-olds to wed with judicial approval. The bill passed unanimously in both houses, and Gov. Cuomo signed it into law on June 20, 2017. Unchained hopes New York will pass additional legislation to eliminate the dangerous exception in the new law.

Ohio.edited-details: SB198 originally would have ended marriage for children 15 and younger, but was amended to end all child marriage. HB511 would allow emancipated 17-year-olds to marry with judicial approval.
Ohio.unchained-details: In September 2017, Sen. Kenny Yuko introduced SB198 to end marriage for children 15 and younger. In February 2018, Rep. Lanese and Rep. Rogers introduced HB511 to limit child marriage: it would allow emancipated 17-year-olds to marry with judicial approval (if their spouse were under 21). HB511 would establish criteria for a judge to consider to approve a marriage. On May 22, 2018, SB198 was amended to end all child marriage in Ohio, without exceptions. Both bills remain pending.

Pennsylvania.edited-details: HB1038, a bill to end all child marriage without exceptions, remains pending.
Pennsylvania.unchained-details: On March 30, 2017, Rep. Perry Warren introduced HB1038, a bill to end all child marriage, without exceptions. The bill remains pending.

Tennessee.edited-details: SB1790 and HB1785, though originally intended to end all marriage before 18 without exceptions, was amended to limit child marriage before it died in a senate committee.
Tennessee.unchained-details: In Jan. 2018, Sen. Jeff Yarbro introduced SB1790 to end all marriage before 18, without exceptions, and Rep. Darren Jernigan introduced a house version of the bill, HB1785. On March 19, 2018, the bill was amended to limit, not end, child marriage before it died in a senate committee on March 28, 2018.

Tennessee 2.edited-details: Unrelated bills HB2134 and SB2268 ended marriage for children 16 and younger but allowed 17-year-olds to marry with parental consent. These bills also establish a civil cause of action for those who have left a forced-marriage.
Tennessee 2.unchained-details: The same day, an unrelated bill, HB2134/SB2268, was amended to end marriage for children 15 and younger. The bill would have allowed 16- and 17-year-olds to marry with parental consent if there were no more than a four-year age difference between spousal pairs. On April 25, 2018, the Tennessee legislature passed HB2134/SB2268, after it was amended to allow only 17-year-olds to marry with parental consent. The bill also establishes a civil cause of action for forced-marriage survivors. On May 21, 2018, the governor signed the bill into law.

Texas.edited-details: SB1705 and HB3932 allows emancipated minors to marry.
Texas.unchained-details: On Mar. 10, 2017, Sen. Van Taylor and Rep. Senfronia Thompson introduced SB1705/HB3932 to end most child marriage but still allow emancipated minors to marry. The senate approved the bill on May 4, and the house approved it May 19. The governor signed the bill on June 15, 2017. Unchained hopes Texas passes additional legislation to eliminate the remaining loophole, under which children can be forced to emancipate and then to marry. Emancipation does not eliminate the many devastating, lifelong consequences of marriage before 18.

Utah.edited-details: HB0343 classifies "subjecting" or "threatening" a child with "a legal or cultural marriage" a matter of sexual abuse.
Utah.unchained-details: HB0343 classifies "subjecting" or "threatening" a child with "a legal or cultural marriage" a matter of sexual abuse.

Vermont.edited-details: H790 would have ended all marriage before 18 without exceptions, but died at the end of the 2018 legislative session.
Vermont.unchained-details: In Jan. 2018, Rep. Carol Ode introduced H790 to end all marriage before 18, without exceptions. The bill died at the end of the legislative session in May 2018. Unchained hopes Vermont legislators will reintroduce this legislation in the next legislative session.

Virginia.edited-details: SB415 and HB703 allows anyone 16 and older to marry with judicial approval.
Virginia.unchained-details: Both houses of the legislature approved SB415/HB703, and governor signed the bill in March 2016. However, the bill did not eliminate all marriage before 18: It allows 16- and 17-year-olds to marry with judicial approval. Unchained hopes Virginia passes additional legislation to eliminate the dangerous exception, under which more than 30 children have married since the law went into effect in July 2016.

Washington.edited-details: HB2376 would have ended marraige for children under 16, but HB3012 would have ended all child marriage without exception. Both died at the end of the legislative session.
Washington.unchained-details: In Jan. 2018, Rep. Joyce McDonald introduced HB2376 to end marriage for children 16 and younger. The bill would not have protected 17-year-olds, who are at the highest risk of forced child marriage. In March 2018, Rep. Derek Stanford introduced HB3012 to end all child marriage, without exceptions. Both bills died at the end of the legislative session in March 2018.

Puerto Rico.edited-details: PS50 made marriage under 18 illegal, but allows girls to marry at ages 16 and 17 if they are pregnant.
